verses.text: Wisdom has built her house; she has set up her seven pillars.
verses.comment: The number seven often symbolizes completeness or perfection in Scripture (see Isa. 11:2; Rev. 1:4). The 'house' embodies the fullness and stability of divine wisdom.

verses.text: She has slaughtered her beasts; she has mixed her wine; she has also set her table.
verses.comment: The banquet imagery foreshadows the eschatological feast (see Isa. 25:6; Matt. 22:2), which later becomes significant in gospel teachings about the kingdom of God.

verses.text: She has sent out her young women to call from the highest places in the town,
verses.comment: Wisdom's invitation is universal and public, highlighting the open call to all people (compare Prov. 1:20–21).

verses.text: "Whoever is simple, let him turn in here!" To him who lacks understanding she says,
verses.comment: An open invitation to those lacking wisdom, correlating with New Testament calls to seek wisdom from above (see Jas. 1:5).

verses.text: "Come, eat of my bread and drink of the wine I have mixed."
verses.comment: Feeding on wisdom is an image later deepened by Christ’s teaching about the bread of life (John 6:51–56), which connects spiritual nourishment to the ultimate banquet established by God.

verses.text: "Leave behind your simple ways, and live; walk in the way of understanding."
verses.comment: A call to conversion and renewed life through pursuing wisdom, echoing the New Testament’s call to walk in spiritual truth (Eph. 5:8).

verses.text: Whoever corrects a scoffer gets shame for himself, and he who reproves a wicked man gets injury.
verses.comment: Wisdom warns of the consequences of correcting the obstinate. Jesus’ words in Matt. 7:6 reflect this teaching.

verses.text: Do not reprove a scoffer, or he will hate you; reprove a wise man, and he will love you.
verses.comment: Reception to correction reveals character. Wisdom brings humility and gratitude for discipline.

verses.text: Give instruction to a wise man, and he will become still wiser; teach a righteous man, and he will increase in learning.
verses.comment: True wisdom leads to ongoing growth; parallels in Jesus’ teaching about the increasing returns of spiritual stewardship (Matt. 13:12).

verses.text: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom, and knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.
verses.comment: The foundation of wisdom is reverence for God; this theme is echoed throughout Scripture (see Ps. 111:10). Knowledge of God is both intellectual and relational (John 17:3).

verses.text: For by me your days will be multiplied, and years will be added to your life.
verses.comment: Embracing wisdom leads to blessings in life, a promise repeated in both Old and New Testaments (Eph. 6:2–3).

verses.text: If you are wise, you are wise for yourself; if you scoff, you alone will bear it.
verses.comment: Personal responsibility for one’s spiritual choices – compare Gal. 6:5 where everyone must carry their own load.

verses.text: The woman of folly is loud; she is gullible and knows nothing.
verses.comment: Folly is personified as a seductress, just as wisdom is personified as a noble woman earlier. This strong contrast sets up a clear moral choice.

verses.text: She sits at the door of her house, on a seat in the high places of the town,
verses.comment: Just as Wisdom calls from the high places (v.3), Folly also sets up her rival invitation, signaling the ever-present alternative to God’s way.

verses.text: calling to those who pass by, who go straight on their way:
verses.comment: Folly’s appeal targets even those who walk uprightly, warning that no one is beyond temptation (1 Cor. 10:12).

verses.text: "Whoever is simple, let him turn in here!" And to him who lacks understanding she says,
verses.comment: Folly imitates Wisdom’s call, suggesting spiritual counterfeits exist (cf. 2 Cor. 11:14–15).

verses.text: "Stolen water is sweet, and bread eaten in secret is pleasant."
verses.comment: Sin is enticing because of its forbidden nature, but scripture warns of deception and empty promises (cf. Prov. 20:17).

verses.text: But he does not know that the dead are there, that her guests are in the depths of Sheol.
verses.comment: Following folly leads to spiritual death—contrasted with Wisdom who gives life, this anticipates the choice Jesus later sets before his followers (see John 5:24; Matt. 7:13–14).
